
Here is a script for you to update `persistent_peers` setting in `config.toml`. Stale peers can cause node inefficiency over time, so the script below selects a few random live peers.

```bash
PEERS=e988e26ccb7238d935d580c899482241fdd9ef99@65.109.84.22:13656,84d74c90514a74000bc47fa6bb62eeb5ffc88fd0@94.130.164.82:20056,141fa8cd4315b89460ea48d557fd6c9148addfb2@65.109.82.230:26656,d8b4abd10feb608db9ed6dd3926dfa85eed3c498@43.131.53.203:26656,7d610ad1f75857c01b45e8b6f25d73457a543611@142.132.209.236:17656
sed -i.bak -e "s/^persistent_peers *=.*/persistent_peers = \"$PEERS\"/" ~/.axoned/config/config.toml

sudo systemctl restart axoned
sudo journalctl -fu axoned --no-hostname -o cat
```

## Our peer for Axone
When you state-sync, you might also consider adding [NODERS]TEAM state-sync peer to your persistent_peers setting in `config.toml`.

```bash
6e4f7d05d9bfec461eaaf10bc10983759078389f@axone-t-rpc.noders.services:20056
```
